awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Artificial Intelligence (AI)-Based Sensing and Data Efficient Sampling, Transmission, Storage, Analysis and Cloud Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve data from sensors that have become ubiquitous in daily life, including personal devices, smart homes and infrastructure, industrial machines and factories, autonomous machines, and the natural environment. Sensor-based ‘big data’ offers real-time visibility into a variety of systems. However, the volume, speed, and variety of this data will soon overwhelm the ability to ingest, refine, and analyze all the data.  This project seeks to develop modeling methodologies that will improve the way data is collected, processed, and analyzed in a variety of industries involving embedded systems such as Internet of Things (IoT), space exploration, and biotechnology. Remote monitoring of industrial machines and distributed sensing in the oceans and the biosphere are some application areas.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel sensor data modeling methodology. Sensor-based data generation is about to reach 73+ trillion gigabytes by 2025. Contemporary data collection and analysis pipelines are inefficient and uneconomical for this scale of data. This technology investigates undersampling for several orders of magnitude savings in data collection, transmission, storage, cloud computing, and analytics. Some application areas include the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT), environmental and ocean monitoring, and autonomous drones and vehicles. The novel methodology in the post-Nyquist era information extraction pipeline centered around undersampling, low-dimensional latent representations, and machine learning, with several orders of savings in the data and engineering complexity of IIoT systems. The insight on undersampling-based learning of low-dimensional latent representations and using them to solve different downstream tasks is the intellectual contribution of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

Sensor-based data generation is about to reach 73+ Trillion GB by 2025. Contemporary data collection and analysis pipelines are inefficient and uneconomical for this scale of data. This work investigates using much less sensor data for order of magnitude savings in data collection, transmission, storage, cloud computing, and analytics. Some application areas include the Industrial Internet of Things, environmental and ocean monitoring, and autonomous drones and vehicles.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The intellectual merit of this project was to explore sensor data reduction for orders of magnitude savings in applications like Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) and space. Recent research suggests that several classes of problems do not require high dimensional data, but only need low dimensional latent representations that can be learned from undersampled sensor measurements. The project resulted in a post-Nyquist era information extraction pipeline centered around undersampling, low-dimensional latent representations, and machine learning, with order of 100x savings in the data and engineering complexity of IIoT systems.

 

Broader Impacts:

Sensors are becoming and will be ubiquitous in all facets of our lives including personal devices, smart homes and infrastructure, industrial machines and factories, autonomous machines, and the natural environment. Sensor-based ‘big data’ offers real-time visibility into a variety of embedded systems. However, the volume, velocity, and variety of this data will soon start overwhelming existing approaches of building engineering pipelines used to ingest, refine, and analyze all this data. Specifically, for edge-based intelligent systems, compute and power are bound to be constrained, which challenges the existing techniques of designing ‘multi-modal big data’ based sensing systems. Moreover, downstream data pipeline components which include data transmission, storage, and computing need to be re-engineered from first principles to exploit the ‘big data’, while still being efficient and economical. This project aims at light-weighting the data collection and the data-engineering pipeline, which will have significant implications in the way data is collected, processed, and analyzed in a variety of industries involving embedded systems such as IoT, IIoT, space exploration, biotechnology, and omics. Remote monitoring of industrial machines and embedded systems, data-efficient digital twins, and distributed sensing-based local-awareness improvement of oceans and the biosphere are some interesting application areas.

 

Key outcomes achieved are as follows:

1. 100+ customer discovery interviews were conducted either in person or virtually to better understand the market requirements. The value proposition of this technology was communicated in short succinct terms to potential customers as a part of the NSF I-Corps training effort.

2. A company (Lightscline) was incorporated during participation in the NSF I-Corps National program.

3. Business Knowledge: EL and PI’s business knowledge was enhanced due to the grant’s emphasis on business training and entrepreneurial mindset generation ideas over the project’s duration.

4. The team got to learn more about patents / licensing / non-dilutive and dilutive funding and got to engage in these efforts. 

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2024
Modified by: Soundar R Kumara
